utterances: And is the reward for that, do you think - obviously, you're giving up some other things in life.
Presumably, by this point, you could be well-launched in a career.
Yeah, but you know, it's - I started doing this kind of late for an athlete.
I started at 15.
I did gymnastics growing up.
And you know, I started having more success kind of later than most people.
Teenagers now are kind of, you know, at where they're starting to peak and get to their fully (ph) level, and I was more starting in my 20s.
And you know, I've been very fortunate.
I have Speedo as my sponsor, and they allow me to train full time.
So I do make a little bit of a living, and I also have a very supportive husband who understands what I do, who was a competitive swimmer in college and coached for five years.
So he was very supportive of what I do.
Excuse me just a second.
David Durante, do you have a sponsor?
Yeah.
My main sponsor is AT&T.
And do you get paid?
You're working at their..
As well as Chevron.
Chevron sponsors our whole U.S.
National Team.
And do you get paid to be a fulltime professional gymnast?
Yes, a very small amount of money, but living at the training center, we have no expenses, so anything that I make from my sponsor I'm able to save
All right.
And Laura Wilkinson, do you get paid by Speedo?
Yes.
I get a salary by Speedo.
We have a contract with them, so they've taken care of me.
That's - so it's actually improved.
We had a caller on earlier from the Olympic team in 1968.
Who said, boy, things were really tough for women in those days.
May I ask how much money you personally made in the tobacco cases?

Yeah, and I mean, still for diving, since it's a smaller sport, so they aren't very many of us that are sponsored, but it's becoming a little easier, and you know, a lot of the people in my sport as well are also at their peak in their teenage years, so a lot of them don't get the support where they need to, making an income after college to keep diving.
Most of them are usually done around college age.
OK.
Well, David Durante, we're going to let you get back to your regimen.
Thanks.
And wish you the best of luck, and I certainly hope we get to see you in Beijing.
I hope so, too.
Thanks for having me on.
David Durante, an alternate on the U.S.
men's 2008 gymnastics team.
He was with us from the Olympic Training Center in Colorado Springs.
And let's see if we can get a caller on the line.
This is Donna.
Donna is with us from Park City in Utah.
Hi, thanks for having me.
Sure, go ahead, please.
I was an Olympic hopeful in the medal debut of women's bobsled in 2002 in Salt Lake.
I got in the sport competitive at this level much later in life, in my early 30s.

The big difference for me was I had come from a very successful corporate career where I had been an officer of a technology company in charge of logistics, so I had a pretty good background in terms of business and a lot of competing at sports at this level, particularly in a capital-intensive sport like bobsled, is kind of about running your own business.
My congratulations go out, also, to Adam Nelson.
I'm also a graduate of the Darden School and that helped me tremendously.
You don't associate immediately business school with competitive athletics.
No, you don't.
But in all sports, they require a significant investment in terms of your training facilities, your equipment, your coaching.
I mean, the expenses, you can rack them up very, very quickly.

And your ability to market yourself and your sport to potential companies is critical, particularly in sports that are very capital-intensive and that have very specialized equipment, building a website, communicating with your people who are supporting you and whether that be financially or emotionally or physically.
But competing at that level is very much like running your own business, particularly if you have to put your own teams together like we did in women's bobsled.

You have to go out there and get athletes, you have to procure highly specialized equipment and then you've got to pay for all your travel, if you're not in the one or two spots on the national team to compete and become competitive at the Olympic level.
Let me ask Laura Wilkinson.
Obviously, you're in an individual sport, not a team sport, and you don't jump off the platform in a bobsled
(Soundbite of laughter
But does - would a business background help you?
I mean, it definitely would.
I understand what she's saying, and I do have my own website and I created it and I run it, and I also did start a foundation.
My pool is actually closing at the end of this year and we need a new pool.
There aren't platforms anywhere near where we are and we have a team that's won the last three nationals in a row, and I'm trying to create - or build a new facility for my team.
So, I do understand what she's saying, and it's hard sometimes, especially when you are in sports that aren't on the TV all the time, except maybe on Olympic time.
You know, we try to capitalize on that, you know, momentum and that excitement around the Games.
But you definitely do have to kind of step out and use those business-type skills.
I don't have that college background.
I mean, I have a college degree, but it wasn't in business, but it definitely comes in handy.
Donna, thanks very much.
It was very interesting.
You're welcome, but she's got the gold medal.
Yeah.
She has her gold, so congratulations.
Thank you.
We're talking with Laura Wilkinson, a gold-medal diver.
You're listening to Talk of the Nation from NPR News.
And I have to ask you, Laura, is it difficult to keep the motivation to do all that work, and work through injuries, and broken bones, and that sort of thing, after you've won a gold medal?
Definitely.
I mean, like anything, you're going to have ups and downs even when it's something you love.
And you know, after I won in Sydney, it was kind of hard to get back on track.
I wasn't sure if I wanted to do it, and I came back in Athens, and you know, I made another Olympic team and I got fifth.
And you know, I understand fifth, at the Olympics, you know, so few people can ever do that ,and it's a great accomplishment, but after having won, it's a little disappointing.
But at the same time, it almost felt like there was a carrot kind of dangled in front of me, like, OK, I know I can do more than this.
I know I can do harder dives, and I can do them better, and it kind of fuels my fire for the next year.
And I learned a whole new list of dives in the last four years.
It definitely has been exciting, not just the same old routine.
Let's get another caller in.
Carolyn, Carolyn with us from Portland, Oregon.
Hello.
Hi.

So I was in the Olympics at 14.
At 16 when I began lifeguarding at $1.25 an hour, I was considered a professional and could not go on with my career
Therefore ineligible.
Ineligible
And again, she was also talking about the difficulties that women had in those days whatever..
Exactly.
With no Title IX, there were no swimming programs in college.
So you all had to it yourselves, pretty much.
You did it.
I know that in Rome I was asked by the Japanese officials if I would be in Tokyo, and I said, no, I won't, I'll be going to college.
Carolyn, thanks very much for the call.
You're welcome.
